Liza Grossman
Music Director, Conductor, Educator

fields.text: This is the upcoming section!

New Works

This concert series focuses on commissioning and premiering a concerto that will feature a member of the Cleveland Orchestra, a College or Conservatory teacher, and local and national musicians.

A work by a young and emerging composer opens this concert series.

A CYO Member is featured as a soloist as a result of our concerto auditions and we study and perform a major work from the 20th or 21st century.

World Premiere:

Liquid Melancholy; concerto for Clarinet and Orchestra
James Stephenson
Daniel Gilbert, clarinet
Co-commissioned by the Contemporary

Additional Concert Program
US Premiere
Traffic Jam, 2010
Jared A. Miller (b. 1988)

Sun-Up

Stephen Katz  (b. 1954)

Lukas Foss (1922-2009)

This is the sidebar

Bam!

It’s one of Liza’s favorite words. And totally representative of the impact she makes on her orchestras and her audiences. Her energy is radiant and infectious and she gives it freely to every student in her orchestras. She is the founding Music Director of the Contemporary Youth Orchestra, conducting faculty at Interlochen Center for the Arts and co-founder of the Interlochen Arts Camp Junior Advanced String Institute. She is director of Orchestras at Kent State University. She also serves as guest conductor for youth orchestras across the country.

Boots

Liza often wears fabulous rocker boots when she’s on the podium conducting her musicians, especially during her Rock the Orchestra series with rock stars like of Styx, Jefferson Starship, Ray Manzarek, Donnie Iris, Graham Nash, Jon Anderson and Pat Benatar. And she has worked some pretty big stages.

Stages

Blossom Music Center. Severance Hall. Nautica Stage. Interlochen. Liza has conducted major artists performing major works on these stages and more, including 20 world-premiere concertos performed by members of the Cleveland Orchestra, nationally recognized musicians and prominent jazz artists. She has conducted more than 100 orchestral world premieres, all with the composers present, including Bernard Rands, Robert Ward and Joan Tower. She is the touring conductor for Styx when they perform with orchestras around the country.

Producer

Liza is the co-executive producer of State of Independence: Jon Anderson and the Contemporary Youth Orchestra and Jefferson Starship and the Contemporary Youth Orchestra.

Reviews/Awards/Media

STRAD magazine called Liza “a master of tutelage...” That’s an understatement. Her student musicians are the real beneficiaries of her skill with the stick and the score. They don’t just get excited to perform. They learn; they grow; they flourish. 

Liza and CYO are the recipients of awards including the Sunshine Award from Young Audiences of Northeast Ohio, the Northern Ohio Live Award of Achievement and the  ASCAP Award for Adventurous Programming

She has been featured numerous times on Cleveland Public Radio WCPN Idea Stream, Cleveland’s Plain Dealer, Scene Magazine, Cool Cleveland, Cleveland Institute of Music Radio ‘Off Beat’, Cleveland Classical Radio WCLV and Cleveland Classical.com. 

Liza Grossman and CYO can be heard on the self released CD, ‘IV: Four World Premiere Concertos’ (iTunes), New Door Records, ‘One With Everything; Styx and the Contemporary Youth Orchestra’ (iTunes), seen on HDNet and PBS internationally with Styx and Jon Anderson. HDNet featured a LIVE broadcast of CYO with Jefferson Starship in 2011 and broadcast a special ‘An evening with the Contemporary Youth Orchestra’ in January 2012, featuring three CYO concerts. CYO is featured on PBS, VH1 Classic and HDNet.

She holds degrees in music performance and music education from Cleveland State University. Her conducting teachers include David Holland, Alexander Schneider, Marvin Rabin and Gerard Schwarz.

CARTUNESTRA!

CYO performs the music of cartoons that feature orchestras, bands and single instruments as the main characters of the cartoons.

Footage and music includes
Pink Panther: Pink, Plunk, Plink
Popeye: Spinach Overture
Silly Symphony: Music Land and many more!

This series was founded in 2007 and designed to expose the CYO
member to different potential professions in different genres one can
have as a professional musician; player, composer, producer, engineer.
The CYO member, our audiences and school age children explore
the many art forms that music relates to in a fun, educational, hands-
on format. Each concert in this series is performed with appropriate
additions to the orchestra, such as the use of film, singers, dancers,
actors, and the composers of these works.

Dr. Daniel Goldmark, professor of music at Case University is a partner
in this series with CYO.
Installments include Tunes for ’Toons (2007), Movie Night (2008),
Broadway! (2009), Don’t Touch That Dial! – TV Themes (2010),
‘Childrens Music with Billy Jonas (2011) and Cartunestra! (2012)

CYO supports education workshops and education concerts
in conjunction with MAII.  If you are interested in learning more, click here.  (need link to page)

Upcoming May 18  Tickets on Sale Soon

Blame Sally

RTO: Rock meets the Orchestra. 

Rock the Orchestra series was founded is 2001.  

This project allows for the study and performance of orchestral pieces that are adapted from rock and popular music.

Funded in part by Cuyahoga Arts and Culture, the Ohio Arts Council, the George Gund Foundation and the Kulas Foundation, this program celebrates music education and the convergence of classical and popular music. This educational endeavor gives students the opportunity to explore how an interest in popular music can be applied to classical music performance studies.

Rock the Orchestra

With CYO you’re likely to be a part of a big time Rock show.  
We are dedicated to exploring all types of contemporary music, and that includes doing shows with influential rock, pop and hip hop artists.  

And there is much to learn from famous performers of popular music.  
They are rock stars for a reason.   

The experience of putting together a show with a famous rock star then performing it in front of thousands is hard to describe. Imagine how Mozart’s band felt at the first performance of his Symphony #41. Or how it feels to play an encore with Styx at Blossom Music Center. Ask the CYO members who played that awesome show.   

Check out some of the shows from past Rock the Orchestra performances and you’ll get an idea why it’s such an important piece of the CYO repertoire, and one of the most popular. More than 150 million people have seen CYO Rock the Orchestra performances broadcast internationally.   

This season’s Rock concert will rock the house, one more time.

The Contemporary Youth Orchestra focuses on creating and performing new music and providing students with a professional kind of musical training. CYO is a symphony orchestra, but it transcends the traditional and prepares young musicians for music, and life, in the real world.

"Behind the Music"

The Contemporary Youth Orchestra makes music that excites the imagination through the study and performance of contemporary music.

CYO develops independent thinkers and leaders while enabling musicians and audiences to expand their perspective and imagination.

Season 18 Auditions

Strings: Saturday, June 2, 2012
Winds, Brass and Percussion: Sunday, June 3, 2012
at Cleveland State University – Music and Communications Building
2001 Euclid Ave. - East 21st and Euclid Ave in Downtown Cleveland

Auditions are by reserved time only, with prepayment of a $20 audition fee. Please apply for an audition by filling out the form. 

You may make your payment at any time here. To request audition fee assistance; please email director@cyorchestra.org. Once we have received your payment and information your audition time will be emailed to the student and parent emails provided in your form. Please add director@cyorchestra.org to your address book as it may be sent to spam folders.

 

Preparing for your Audition!

Strings

Scales: One three-octave major and minor scale of our choice. One scale slurred, 6 per bow; One scale spiccato; 1, 2, 3 or 4 strokes per pitch

Solo Piece: Your choice of style and genre
Sight-reading: We will supply you with a short excerpt
Prepared excerpt: download here (link)

Woodwinds

Scales: 

Flutes: one three-octave major and minor scale and chromatic scale of our choice. Slurred and tongued.
Oboes, Clarinets, Bassoons: one two-octave major and minor scale and chromatic scale of our choice. Slurred and tongued.
Solo Piece: Your choice of style and genre
Sight-reading: We will supply you with a short excerpt
Prepared excerpt: download here (link)

Brass

Scales: One two-octave major and minor scale of our choice slurred and articulated.

Solo Piece: Your choice of style and genre
Sight-reading: We will supply you with a short excerpt
Prepared excerpt: download here (link)

Percussion

Scales: One two-octave major and minor scale of our choice on mallet instrument.

Demonstrate ability on: Snare, Timpani and Mallet
Sight-reading: we will supply you with a short excerpt
Prepared excerpt: download here (link)

Liquid Melancholy

James Stephenson
Daniel Gilbert, clarinet
Danzon No. 2 – Arturo Marquez

New Works

If you’re looking for Beethoven and Mozart you’re in the wrong place.  

CYO creates Contemporary music. Every season we perform new works  and explore new composers and genres.  We learn all about each piece from the composer who creates it. CYO pursues the New with relentless energy and excitement. This makes CYO a different kind of musical experience, all about learning how the music of today is created, prepared and performed.   

This season is no different.

Welcome!

If you're looking for Mozart or Beethoven, you're in the wrong place.

Here, we make new music.

We put our heads and hands and hearts into it.  And we share it with excitement, energy and joy.    

Under the effusive, visionary leadership of Conductor/Music Director/Founder, Liza Grossman, CYO has become one of the premiere youth orchestras in the country. Since 1995, thousands of young musicians have passed through our ranks. We look forward to getting to know thousands more.   

Take a look around our site and get to know us. 

Proudly in residence at Cleveland State University

CYO rocked Nautica Stage with Jefferson Starship on a perfect early summer evening, performing the rock classics that blossomed in the San Francisco music scene in the late sixties and influenced the rock and pop music for decades. The show was broadcast live and has been seen by more than 30 million people worldwide.

Music and It's Industry

Music and its Industry series adds dimension, depth and fun to our musicians’ overall education; rehearsing a professional show and performing it with the artists that created it.   

MAIII concerts help our players learn more about musical independence, teaching them practice and performance techniques they will use in their professional lives. They learn about what the real world of music looks like and how it works. They learn how to collaborate with professional artists in rehearsal and in concert. And they learn to perform like pros in some very cool concerts.   

These concerts are wildly different.

This season promises to bring the CYO difference to the stage once again.

CYO musicians learn how to play original, contemporary music in the real world, through collaboration with the professional artists who created it. This is done from the ground up in collaboration with the composers.  

These young musicians are unique people, displaying an energy, excitement and commitment that elevate everyone who comes in contact with it.

These are the young musicians who want a different experience from their music and their interaction with it. Something alive!

An experience beyond Mozart and Beethoven.  

That's why the concerts are so exciting and so much fun.   

These things they learn here and their great performances follow them through their lives.

This we know, because so many of our musicians return to visit, participate, to help and to let us know how they're doing.

Your support can help CYO to remain healthy, innovative and vital. And help us to keep talented young musicians in their chairs.  

You can help in a variety of ways – donation; scholarship; endowment; subscription; volunteer; sponsorship; ticket purchases.

Any level of support will help CYO to continue to flourish as one of the premiere youth orchestras in the country.

CYO is a 501 (c) 3 organization. All donations are tax deductible to the full extent of IRS determinations.

There are many a ways for you to contribute to the orchestra! Your donation can be as broad or as specific as you like.

Contribute to the General Fund

The CYO maintains a general fund that allows for the purchase of music and the hundreds of details that make a performance possible. The General Fund offers many levels of support:

Podium   
$5000 and above  

Score      
$1000 - $4999   

Baton     
$500 - $999   

Grand Staff   
$250 - $499   

Whole Note   
$100 - $249   

Half Note  
$50 - $99

Quarter Note
$5 - $49

What are you waiting for? Donate NOW!

Endow a Chair

You can endow an orchestra chair in your name for a three-year pledge of $300. Or, for a one-time donation of $10,000, endow a chair in perpetuity in your name.

CYO also offers various levels of alumni chairs and an open-giving "Friends of CYO" chair. Young musicians seated in endowed chairs receive $100 toward their CYO commitments because of their musical achievements.   

Endow a Scholarship

Provide a gifted young musician the opportunity to transform their musical life. These scholarships allow any young musician, regardless of their financial situation, to join our ranks.

Sponsor a Guest Artist

You can help provide our young musicians with the opportunity to work face to face with international artists and composers.

Purchase tickets

Ticket purchase and concert attendance is the most basic and necessary way to support CYO.    

Become a subscriber

Your season subscription helps us to better plan and budget for upcoming events, and helps you to reserve a great seat for every show.

Thank you, you can be sure that your donation goes a long way!

CYO and our members perform throughout the year at schools and special events. You can enjoy the entire orchestra or request smaller chamber groups from within group.

Past CYO road performances include: 

Hanna Theater Grand Opening – Cleveland, Ohio

Great Lakes Science Center Opening of the Body Exhibit – Cleveland, Ohio

Health Space Grand Opening – Cleveland, Ohio

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum – Case Western Reserve University

American Music Masters Concert honoring Roy Orbison – Cleveland, Ohio

Soldiers and Sailors Hall Pennsylvania premiere of Horn Concerto featuring Cleveland Orchestra Principal Horn, Richard KingPublic School Performances – CYO performs at several schools during the season as part of our Music Education Outreach program

Contact the General Manager for information about your CYO performance.

Events in 2012

February 23, 6pm Reading and Recording Session for CYO Community Compositions

For this annual event members of the CYO community, including musicians and alumni, submit compositions to be site read and recorded for college applications, auditions, submissions and celebration!

Music and Its Industry: The BEST of CARTUNESTRA!

Thursday, March 22, 2012, 7:30pm 
Chagrin Falls High School Performing Arts Center

CYO joins forces with the Chagrin High School Music community to bring the best of CYO’s Music and Its Industry to the Chagrin Valley.

SPECIAL CONCERT: Tri-C Metro – Project Gilgamesh with composer Daniel Bernard Roumain

Thursday, April 5th 7pm concert, (Click here for more details)

At a “creative campus.” At Tri-C. Using The Epic of Gilgamesh as a starting point, Tri-C’s “Project Gilgamesh” asks guest artist Daniel Bernard Roumain to create a contemporary response to an ancient story.

Roumain’s music and the story of Gilgamesh will inspire classroom explorations into the text and its themes and spark artistic projects campus-wide during the 2011-2012 academic year. Project Gilgamesh is a multi-year, nationally funded, college-wide collaboration among Tri-C faculty, students, administration, guest artists, and partnering organizations such as The Cleveland Museum of Art and Great Lakes Theater.

More information

The Contemporary Youth Orchestra receives support for our scholarship program through orchestral chairs. Each chair contributor has pledged ongoing scholarship support for the outstanding musicians in the orchestra for their particular achievements.

Merit chair recipients are announced at the annual recognition night in June for the following season. The recipient receives a scholarship of $100.

Endowed Chairs are supported by one-time gifts to sustain scholarship and recognition for CYO programs and activities.

Endowed Chairs

Sersig/Brandt Family Chair is a full scholarship to CYO. The award is given with priority to a musician in the viola, trumpet, or clarinet sections. The chair was established in recognition of Liza Grossman's talent in nurturing young musicians. Andrew Brandt (CYO 2004-2008) studied viola with Liza from 2000-2007. Trumpet and clarinet are the instruments of Andrew’s siblings.

Beytas Family Chair recognizes an outstanding musician’s balanced achievement in academic and music performance. Priority is given to students in the string section. David Beytas was a member of the Contemporary Youth Orchestra viola section from 2005-2009.

Merit Chairs

Alumni Chair: This chair is awarded to a current CYO member who shows exemplary dedication to the craft of their instrument and the responsibility of performing new music.

John and Nicole Clouser Chair: John Clouser is the principal bassoon in the Cleveland Orchestra. The recipient of this chair is a bassoon player who has shown growth and dedication to the instrument and the orchestra. This chair was first awarded in 2001.

Friends of CYO Chair: This chair is supported by donors and is for a student who contributes to CYO through his/her enthusiasm and joy in participating in music performance and rehearsals. This chair was first awarded in 2001.

Frisof Family Chair: Marie and Sarah Frisof were charter members of CYO. David followed soon after. The recipient of this chair rotates among viola, flute and cello, going to a member who represents passion for music and education. The Frisof family provided key support to establish CYO. This chair was first awarded in 2005.

M. Glenn Grossman Memorial Chair: This chair is in honor of the memory M. Glenn Grossman. It is awarded to a student that exemplifies the joy and thrill of playing music. This chair was first awarded in 2002.

Mark Jackobs Chair: Mark Jackobs is a violist with the Cleveland Orchestra. The recipient of this chair is a violist who has shown significant growth and added quality to the section. This chair was first awarded in 2001.

Richard King Chair: Richard King is the principal horn player of the Cleveland Orchestra. He and his family have been supporters of CYO since its inception. The recipient of this chair is a horn player who has shown significant growth and possesses leadership qualities. This chair was first awarded in 2001.

Daniel Rains Memorial Chair: Daniel Rains was the orchestra conductor and a violin instructor at Cleveland State University from 1985-2001. He was a master technician and instructor. This recipient of this chair is a student who is dedicated to learning their craft. This chair was first awarded in 2001.

Sords Family Chair: Andrew Sords, violinist, graduated from CYO in 2004. A member of CYO for eight years, he was concertmaster for four of those years. The Sords family provided key support to establish CYO. The recipient of this chair is a violin player with strength, leadership skills, and dedication. This chair was first awarded in 2005.

Steve Witser Memorial Chair: Steve Witser was a member of The Cleveland Orchestra and the principal trombone of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Steve was a foundation supporter of CYO, a soloist with the orchestra and a scholarship chair supporter for 7 years. The chair is awarded to students throughout the brass section. This chair was first awarded in 2001 and then continued in Steve's honor in 2008.

Conductors Award: This recipient of this award is dedicated to the study and performance of new music, enjoys their surroundings and embodies the spirit of CYO. This chair was first awarded in 2001.

Hello
Archives

Singer/Songwriter Contest

CYO is sponsoring a song writing contest with the winning selections from 5 age groups to be performed in fully orchestrated versions for CYO’s March 2013 Music and Its Industry concerts.  
Current CYO musicians and alumni songs will be showcased alongside the song contest winners.

Music and Its Industry Workshops

Music and Its Industry is an ongoing education outreach program of the Contemporary Youth Orchestra.

Music and Its Industry (MAII) engages children in an intensive, hands-on music learning experience to study music, orchestral instruments, performance and visual arts through intense personal arts experiences.  

Through a series of six artist contact workshop sessions, beginning with teacher orientation and continuing with classrooms experiencing a hands-on curriculum, students engage with orchestral instruments linked to a changing curriculum reflecting an annual industry theme.  

Past programs have included Television Themes, Cartoons, Movie Theme Music, Broadway, and Family Friendly Music Performance with Billy Jonas. 

To inquire about workshops in your school, contact sheppard@cyorchestra.org

The curriculum, developed by CYO, highlights potential careers in the industry, stresses basic language arts skill development and encourages achievement.  

Teachers participate in pre-workshop sessions to facilitate integration and extension of the workshops into core curriculum.  All workshops encompass hands-on learning in art, music and writing.  

A team of artists/educators including Robin Pease, drama and language arts specialist and Dave Young, musician and composer, leads the sessions.  The final workshop presentations are recorded.  

The program culminates in a 55- minute daytime concert performed by the Contemporary Youth Orchestra on the campus of Cleveland State University.  The concert reinforces the education and skills emphasized in the workshops.

Without these unique young musicians, CYO is just another youth orchestra. Because they look for more from music, and from life, our entire organization is transformed. Here’s where we spotlight some of these young musicians.

I am a Kent State University graduate from which I graduated Summa Cum Laude. I majored in English and obtained a Spanish minor as well. I'm currently working as a graduate assistant in the Honors College at Kent where I am an academic advisor for 72 Honors College freshmen.

I would also like to mention that we have lots of events for Honors and I get to meet the rapper, Common, in February when he comes for a lecture series, so I have a pretty amazing job. I am getting my master's degree in Library and Information Science. I want to either work as an archivist, a music librarian, or a medical librarian at a hospital (the Rock Hall would be a cool place to work too!)

I know that sounds like an odd pathway perhaps, when I was so involved in music, but I never wanted to make music into a job for me, so I just keep up with it for fun now. When I was an undergrad I played one year in the Kent State University orchestra but stopped because it was too many hours a week with my major and minor, however I was always in other groups that played out around the city. I've been in a sort of indie rock group and also a bluegrass group since I was in college. We mostly play for fun and sometimes out too. I also got to record with a western swing group based near Oberlin.

CYO I think gave me in part the courage to try different styles of music and play with other people. Despite being an English major, music is always an ever-present part of my life. I've also just played with and jammed with countless groups and people since coming to Kent, we have a great folk scene here and there is always something going on. I may go to Columbus in a month or so to record with a folk singer there (he calls himself American War).

As for classical music, although I stopped playing in the Kent State orchestra, I took up singing. I've been singing in the Kent chorus now for two semesters. We sang Dona Nobis Pachem with the Canton Symphony this past spring which was incredible. I of course played violin so singing is new to me, but I'm getting to be a better vocalist by being in this group and following the example of others around me. It's comprised of community members and students.

Which leads me to the point I'm trying to make; music has always been a way for me to feel a part of something no matter where I am and CYO opened up my mind so that I could play with so many types of people. I had no idea how to play bluegrass music a couple years ago but now I can. I had only ever read music off the page and I had no idea how to play leads or make parts up but since then I've improved a bit. I've met a girl who plays the mandolin and does a lot of Delta blues stuff. It's incredible the people you can find and connect with through music.

So my advice to any CYO members would be--never stop making music. Even after college. There is really no excuse. You can always find local groups to sing or play with. You can do whatever you want for a job and keep music as your passion too.

The other thing is to be proud of what you did in CYO. For me music is a way to connect with people and something to be proud of. Once you get to college people will be surprised and admiring that you can play violin or any instrument. Usually when I talk to people their biggest regret is that they didn't keep up with the instrument they were learning and I always try to explain to them that it's not too late, you can pick it up again or do something different.

CYO also taught me to keep an open mind about all types of music. I still bring up in conversation when we played Symphonic Led Zeppelin, although that was four years ago. Four years is such a short time, but also a long time if those four years were your college years when you were growing up so much. I also got into writing poetry in college and it showed me that creativity flows over all levels... you can keep music, writing, anything really and it just makes you a more well-rounded, happy person no matter where you go. Some people go to the gym to relieve stress, I break out my violin and play.

Thank you much for the experiences, I hope that this note finds you well and happy.

Best, Jamie

Jamie Bloss
Kent State University
The Honors College
A Community of Scholars

Jennifer Juan, Graphic Design

Jennifer has been the graphic designer for CYO since 2003.

Jennifer received her degree in visual communication from Ohio State University, and has also studied graphic design at the Schule für Gestaltung in St. Gallen, Switzerland. During her last year at Ohio State, Jennifer interned at VIA, Inc. and was hired as a full-time graphic designer upon her graduation. While in Columbus, Jennifer received two Awards of Excellence and one Award of Merit from the Columbus Society of Communicating Arts (CSCA) for her graphic design work. She then moved back home to Cleveland to work for marchFIRST’s Cleveland Brand Building Group, where she focused on web design. Jennifer parlayed her talents into a position with designRoom Creative, where she spent 10 years handling design work for clients such as American Greetings, Burt's Bee, and the Cleveland Clinic.

She is currently the Graphic Artist for WVIZ/PBS & 90.3 WCPN Ideastream.

She really likes mangos.

Idea Stream

David Yost, Recording Engineer

David Yost has been the Recording Engineer for CYO since 1999.

David Yost has been involved in professional audio and recording, music store retail, and electronic music for thirty-nine years. He has been with the Cleveland State University music department since 1999 and is responsible for all departmental recording and archiving, as well as live sound events.

In addition to his duties at CSU, he is the recording engineer for the Award winning Contemporary Youth Orchestra. He has recorded their concerts since 1999, including major rock shows with artists Pat Benatar, Styx, Jon Anderson and Jefferson Starship. He is the recording engineer for the world-renowned Cleveland Chamber Symphony, as well as the local Cleveland Philharmonic. His engineering credits include the 2007 Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Soloist(s) Performance (with Orchestra) awarded the Cleveland Chamber Symphony, of Olivier Messiaen's 'Oiseaux Exotiques'. This Grammy is the result of just one of his more than fifty professional classical recording sessions at Cleveland State University. Through his privately owned CD mastering and classical recording business, Concerto Recording and Mastering, David has engineered over five hundred commercial CD releases and over fifty location concert recordings.

Mr. Yost holds an FCC amateur radio Extra Class license and is a member of the Audio Engineering Society, the Cuyahoga Amateur Radio Society, and the American Radio Relay League. He is the recipient of the 2011 Distinguished Service Award from the Contemporary Youth Orchestra.

Concert Recording

Angelo LaMarco, Videographer

Angelo LeMarco has been the CYO videographer since its inception in 1995.

Angelo LaMarco, has over 35 years of experience as a performing artist and heads the Digital Edge Video Services. He trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts in London, England. Angelo also holds certificates in video production from NYU Film School and in digital audio engineering and music theory from The Recording Institute of Detroit.

As videographer to Cleveland's Rock & Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, The Digital Edge has filmed over 300 live concerts that read like a virtual "who's who" of Rock & Roll history. The Digital Edge Video Productions also specializes in multi-camera coverage of theatrical stage productions such as classical orchestra concerts, as well as commercials aired nationally. In addition to filming the concerts of CYO, he has filmed all the backstage work of CYO for major productions including Styx, Jon Anderson and Jefferson Starship. He is the recipient of the 2012 Distinguished Service Award from the Contemporary Youth Orchestra.

Digital Eddge Production 

James Zammikiel, Lighting designer

James Zammikiel has been the CYO Lighting Designer since 2001.

Jamie has numerous specialties including programming and design with automated ﬁxtures, rigging and power distribution. He has a Bachelors Degree in Technical Production for Lighting and Sound from Ohio University and multiple professional certiﬁcations.

Jamie especially enjoys highly creative projects where he is able to collaborate with his peers on all the aspects of a shows design from the inception.

He has worked with people including Bob Peterson (MTV and Alan Jackson), Emmy Award winning lighting designer Jeff Ravitz, Playhouse Square, Cleveland Playhouse, Liza Grossman, Rob Weil, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, and Mary Tarantino.

IMDB

Here at CYO we have productions we would like to share with you. Generally we have concerts in December, March, and May. We also have surprises for our contemporary music fanatics in between. Below you can check out our concert information!

March 2011

CYO meets Circus and Vaudeville!

The Bindlestiff Family Circus joins forces with CYO to explore the music that accompanies trapeze artists, clowns, contortionists, tightrope walkers and all the acts you’ll find in a circus. The circus is one of the few remaining performing arts groups that still tours with live musicians. This installment in this series will exemplify what it takes to be a circus musician. And it’s a tough gig.

CYO meets Circus and Vaudeville!

The Bindlestiff Family Circus [http://www.bindlestiff.org/] joins forces with CYO to explore the music that accompanies trapeze artists, clowns, contortionists, tightrope walkers and all the acts you’ll find in a circus. The circus is one of the few remaining performing arts groups that still tours with live musicians. This installment in this series will exemplify what it takes to be a circus musician. And it’s a tough gig.

Music man Peter Bufano, head of Cirkestra, will supply the music. Peter was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut (the home town of P.T. Barnum). He’s a graduate of The Berklee College Of Music as well as Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Clown College. Peter’s music can be heard on stage, in film, on television, radio and under the big top. He has run away to join the circus on more than one occasion and his appearances in the ring have played to hundreds of thousands of people across the U.S. and Japan.

Peter calls Boston home but has been seen playing piano and accordion across the United States with Ringling Bros, Barnum & Bailey Circus, The Bindlestiff Circus, Circus Smirkus, Big Apple Circus, Kinoshita Circus of Japan and with his band Cirkestra [http://www.cirkestra.com].

Traffic Jam for Large Orchestra

US Premiere:

2010 Traffic Jam for Large Orchestra
Jared Miller
Premiered by the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra

“This piece was composed as a commission from the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra for the 2010 Winter Olympics. As a result of the success of its initial performances in December 2009, the orchestra programmed it an additional seven times last season, including six performances in the VSO’s elementary school concert series and their annual Concert in the Park. More than 25 000 young people around British Columbia were able to hear and enjoy my music.”
Jared Miller, Composer

CYO had its first rehearsal in 1995. Conductor and founder Liza Grossman stood in front of a small group of eager young musicians, lifted her baton, brought it down and it was on. CYO has been in go mode ever since, with a vision to excite the imagination with every concert and every season.

CYO flourishes year-to-year in large part because of the intense, committed involvement of our Board members. This dedicated group spends a remarkable amount of time making concerts happen, managing budgets, raising funds and wisely steering the CYO ship, so we can continue to share our exciting musical mission with young musicians and audiences.

Kate Sheppard, General Manager

Kate Sheppard is General Manager of the Contemporary Youth Orchestra. An alumni parent and former member of the Board of Trustees, Kate volunteered as data manager and grant writer from 2003-2008. She continues to volunteer as grant writer after assuming duties of GM in 2008. Kate holds a BA from Pomona College in mathematical economics and a PhD in economics from the University of Maryland, College Park.

Currently part time Senior Instructor at the University of Akron teaching undergraduate and graduate macroeconomics, Kate has been on the faculty at Skidmore College, the College of Wooster and, through a Fulbright Scholarship in Bulgaria in 1995-06, Sofia University and The University of National and World Economics. Kate has been an Affiliate Support Manager and Midwest Regional Director for Habitat for Humanity, International and served on the board, including as Board Treasurer, of Case Barlow Farm, Hudson, OH. Kate is the parent of trombonist Rob Sheppard-Sage, CYO alumnus and recent graduate in performance and music education Carnegie Mellon University.

Daniel Goldmark, Associate Professor, Musicology, Case Western Reserve University

Daniel Goldmark has been a collaborator with the CYO original series, Music And Its Industry since its inception in 2007.

He joined the Department of Music in 2005, works on American popular music, film and cartoon music, and the history of the music industry, film and cartoon music, and the history of the music industry. He received his B.A. in music from the University of California, Riverside. Goldmark received both a M.A. and Ph.D. in Musicology from the University of California, Los Angeles, with a dissertation titled Happy Harmonies: Music and the Hollywood Animated Cartoon. Goldmark co-edited The Cartoon Music Book (A Cappella, 2001), Beyond the Soundtrack: Representing Music in Cinema (California, 2007), and Funny Pictures: Animation and Comedy in Studio-Era Hollywood (California, in press). His monograph, Tunes for ‘Toons: Music and the Hollywood Cartoon, was published in 2005. His current research is on music publishing, Tin Pan Alley in the early 1900s, and music publishing in Cleveland, including the music of Cleveland-born composer J.S. Zamecnik. He is the series editor of the Oxford Music/Media Series from Oxford University Press, and is a senior editor for The Grove Dictionary of American Music, 2nd edition. In 2010 he began a three-year term as the review editor for the Journal of the American Musicological Society.

Faculty Web Page [Case Western University]

Dave Young

Dave Young has worked with Music and Its Industry since its first season in 2007 with Tunes for Toons, and all subsequent programs including Movie Night, Broadway, Television Themes and Whammin’Slamin’ and Jammin! Dave represents Young Audiences of Northeast Ohio.

He has composed and recorded music for TV, radio, industrial film and multi-media presentations ranging from local to international projects. In his nearly 20 years of experience, this classically-trained musician has diverse experiences including playing in a Calypso World Beat Band, being on the roster of Young Audiences in the San Francisco Bay Area to co-writing the music for several popular Sega CD ROM games.

Robin Pease

Robin Pease has worked with Music and Its Industry since 2008 for Movie Night, Broadway , Television Themes and Whammin’Slammin’ and Jammin! She holds a Master of Fine Arts from Case Western Reserve University and a Bachelor of Fine Arts from The Boston Conservatory. She has performed and taught drama, music, dance and multiculturalism for students of all ages throughout the country. Robin is a member of the Actors' Equity Association and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. Robin presents Young Audiences of Northeast Ohio.

Paul Leary

Paul Leary has been arranging music for CYO since 2002.

Originally a Southern California native, he attended the University of Michigan and in 1999 received his Bachelor’s in Music Composition. There he studied with William Albright, Erik Santos, and Michael Dougherty. His graduate work brought him to the Cleveland Institute of Music (CIM), where he received his Masters in Music Composition in May 2002. He also attended the summer program, La Scola Catorum in Paris, France under the direction of Phillip Lasser. During his studies at CIM, Paul taught music theory at Case Western Reserve University (CWRU). He received his DMA in composition from Duke University in 2012.

Contemporary Youth Orchestra commissioned and premiered Concerto for Trumpet, Turntables, and Orchestra. Horn Sonata was premiered by Richard King, principal horn of the Cleveland Orchestra, and has been played all around the world. Paul has arranged/orchestrated close to 200 pieces for CYO including music from Cartoons, Movies, TV Themes, Broadway, Children’s Music, Jazz Standards

His work, “I have a Past Life Memory of the War that Blew the Fifth Planet into the Asteroid Belt” for sax quartet and electronics was chosen as a finalist at the 2007 International Computer Music Conference in Copenhagen, Denmark. It will also be performed at the Florida State New Music Festival in Florida in Jan. 2009 and is the winner of the Look and Listen composition competition in New York City. In 2005, Paul became a part-time lecturer at Case Western Reserve University teaches computer music.

He was one of the major contributing orchestrators for Contemporary Youth Orchestra productions Classical Nash with Graham Nash; Fire Away with Pat Benatar; One With Everything with Styx; Symphonic Led Zeppelin; Donnie Iris; Farandole, Classical Hip-Hop; State Of Independence, with Jon Anderson and Jefferson Starship.

http://www.pauleary.com/

 

Peter Mowrey

Peter Mowrey has been arranging music for CYO since 2003.

He is Associate Professor of Music at the College of Wooster (Ohio), where he has taught composition, music theory, piano, and music technology since his arrival in 1997. His degrees include a B.Mus. in Piano Performance (1989) and M.M. in Composition (1991) from the University of Georgia, and a D.M. in Composition (1995) from Indiana University. As a pianist, he has specialized in chamber music; performance highlights include Franck's Symphonic Variations with the UGA Orchestra, Joan Tower's Black Topaz (piano and chamber ensemble) on live radio, and Peter Maxwell Davies' Missa super l'homme arme (voice, keyboards, and chamber group) at the Spoleto festival in Charleston. His compositions include Toccata for piano, the national runner-up in the MTNA Collegiate Composition Contest (1990); a sextet for mixed ensemble which won the Philip Slates Composition Contest in 1994; The Hero's Journey, a six-movement piano piece in honor of Joseph Campbell; and many chamber works and electronic compositions, including The Masks of God: An Homage to Joseph Campbell, for electronics and dancers. His most recent major composition is The Pavilion of Dreams, a two-act opera for seven singers and electronic orchestra.

Dr. Mowrey has done orchestral arranging for the Contemporary Youth Orchestra (Cleveland), primarily for the rock artists who have performed with the ensemble as part of the ongoing “Rock the Orchestra” program. These arrangements include works for Styx, Donnie Iris, Jon Anderson and Jefferson Starship. Mowrey is also the author of Award Winning Films: A Viewer's Reference to 2700 Acclaimed Motion Pictures (McFarland & Company, 1994).

http://www.wooster.edu/Academics/Areas-of-Study/Music/Faculty-and-Staff/Peter-Mowrey


Stefan Podell

Stefan Podell has been arranging music for CYO since 2009.

Stefan grew up in a very musical home. His father was an accomplished jazz saxophone and clarinet player. Common instruments could often be found lying around the house alongside instruments you wouldn't expect. From a baby grand piano (now in Stefan's living room inspiring his own children) to a sousaphone he practically had to climb into to play, it was all fair game.

Like any teenager would, Stefan ultimately had to choose a loud instrument to play. Guitar was it. Years of lessons studying rock, classical, and jazz created a hybrid style that informs his work as a player and composer.

Now a sought-after composer, arranger, and orchestrator, Stefan has created works for artists such as Jon Anderson of YES, Jefferson Starship, Evelyn Glennie, the Contemporary Youth Orchestra, and Sean Beeson.

As a songwriter and musician, Stefan has won awards from the likes of Billboard Magazine and VH-1. He has shared the stage with performers such as Cheap Trick, Barenaked Ladies, and Dishwalla.

Stefan has studied Spud Murphy's Equal Interval System <http://equalinterval.com/> 
with David Blumberg <http://tribute2david.com/> and composition with Leon Willett <http://leonwillett.com/>

http://stefanpodell.com/
